participants.participant: Nathalie Errard, Head of Investor Relations
Hans Peter Ring, Chief Financial Officer

plist.p: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the EADS Full Year 2008 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, all participants have been placed on a listen-only mode. The floor will be open for questions following the presentation.
Let me now turn the floor over to your hosts Louis Gallois, Hans Peter Ring and Nathalie Errard.

Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is EADS's 2008 Earnings Conference Call. Louis Gallois, our CEO and Hans Peter Ring, our CFO, will be presenting our results and answering your questions. This call is planned to last about one hour and 30 minutes. It includes Q&A, which we will conduct after the initial presentation.

It is also web cast on our website. Playback of this call will also be accessible on the website, but there is no dedicated phone replay service. The supporting information package was e-mailed to you two hours ago with slides, which we will now walk through and financial statements.

Throughout this call, we will be making forward-looking statements. The packages you received contain a Safe Harbor statement, which applies to this call as well. We believe you should read it carefully.
Now to Louis Gallois.

Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you for joining us for this review of our 2008 performance. I come to this discussion with a combination of confidence and caution. The confidence flows from my strong belief in what this company, its management and employees can achieve despite difficult challenges.
As you will see from our 2008 highlights EADS has maintained a strong financial perform and achieved a number of significant accomplishments despite its program challenges.

The caution, you are not surprised, stems from the difficult economic environment that faces most companies in most industries worldwide. Yet in our case I believe that we have learned in redesigning our company in the past years with, will help us weather the current downturn. I think it is important to keep in mind several factors as we discuss our results.

So first is that the commercial speed of this company stronger than ever as our sale successes of 2008 indicate. Every division has contributed to a strong product backlog, and we are creating new opportunities and services. The second is that we are substantially more integrated, more efficient company. This is a continuous, it's not finished and challenging process, but we have come a long way as a business enterprise.

The third is that while we are managing the risk that we face and therefore have spoken to you frankly about this in past, in past meetings, I believe that EADS should expect the cooperation of European governments in resolving some of these issues. Certainly this is a case with the critical program such as the A400M.
With this in mind, let me turn towards the highlights of 2008 on page four, before that have a close look please at our Safe Harbor statement on page two.

Commercial success and strategic progress have delivered a solid set of results. Our record order book, now at more than €400 billion with different activities at €55 billion provides stability and a certain level of visibility. 2008 was a year of ramp up activity. Airbus delivered a record 483 aircraft, 30 more than in 2007 including 12 A380. Substantial reorganization of production lines and the opening of new facilities in Eurocopter enabled a 20% increase in deliveries. 588 helicopters were delivered in the year.

IM5 achieved six launches during the year. It has provide, proved highly, it has proved highly reliable performing 28 successful launches in a row. This commercial performance intersects with solid financial results.

Our underlying business has led to better than expected cash flow generation and a solid EBIT performance, which was also boosted by significant currency impact. Each of our divisions have made strategic advances during this year.

For Airbus, the mandate has been a resilient and far more integrated operation that can better execute. In the case of Eurocopter, I think you are seeing the template of EADS evolving business model. Substantial success on military helicopters in both the U.S. and Brazil demonstrate progress in the move towards globalization. Our focus on maximizing high margin services provides some protection against the commercial cycle.

Defence and space activities are delivering profitable growth through a combination of efficiency and productivity initiatives as well as external growth. So taken as a full picture, 2008 was a very solid year for our company.

Since efficiency is going to be critical for EADS in the years to come, let me walk you through the Power8 achievement to-date. Through a new organizational structure, leaner processes and careful cash management, Power8 has significantly reduced Airbus cost base for the long-term. For the second year in a row, it exceeded targets, delivering gross cost savings of about €1.3 billion compared to the projected base line of the costs. This is more than half way to the €2.1 billion 2010 confirmed objective. Reduced overhead costs have already delivered 50% of the original target of 10,000. Smart buying is delivering result and lean manufacturing has now been deployed in all plants, enabling tighter control on working capital.

On top of Power8 and in case of further weakening in the market, we will review expenses in all areas. The divestment of non-core infrastructure sites has also progressed despite a difficult financial climate. Laupheim and Filton sites have been sold to long-term Airbus partners, enabling Airbus to concentrate on its core business as aircraft architect and integrator in the future. I remind you the, also the creation of Aerolia in France and Premium Aerotech in Germany from our aerostructure facilities.

Power8 PLUS and the EADS wide effort leading to €1 billion additional savings in 2011 and 2012 will meet its targets through cost reduction project and a focus on expanding industrial footprint and an increasing level of U.S. dollar sourcing in the cost base.

Within the scope of the future EADS program, EADS has adopted a simpler and leaner organization. Our Military Transport Aircraft division is now integrated within Airbus, maximizing synergies and reinforcing the management of the new entity Airbus Military inside Airbus.

Space and defence divisions will develop a consistent approach towards common customers and develop commercial, technical and strategic synergies. Support functions are currently under review, real estate, facility management and general procurement will be organized in a shared service to standardize processes and leverage economies of scale and efficiency.
Let me now turn to Hans Peter to discuss the financial picture in more detail. Hans Peter?

Thank you, Louis and good morning everybody. I'm on page six. We have kept you regularly updated on the delayed A400M program. You are aware of the new approach we made to OCCAR to solve the technical and contractual issues. We have recently strengthened the program management by integrating MTAD into Airbus, creating Airbus Military. This will optimize resources and streamline decision-making.

For the full year 2008 financial statements we have adopted a temporary accounting treatment allowed under IFRS 11. The high level of uncertainty leads us to maintain early stage accounting and suspend the milestone accounting. Therefore the net EBITDA impact of minus €700 million taken does not reflect the complete new estimate of the loss at completion.

Once the situation becomes clear we will resume the milestone accounting and update the provision in its entire scope. Obviously, the magnitude of the final adjustment will be dependant on the outcome of the overall assessment of the A400M program and of negotiations with customers and suppliers.

You will see in the press release that OCCAR has the right to cancel the contract and to recover all initial and pre-delivery payments. It requires unanimous consent from the different nations, and we do not expect OCCAR to cancel the contract at this stage. Formal negotiations will begin in the coming weeks.

If we now turn the pages, to page eight to the financial highlights. 2008 results demonstrate a combination of top and bottom-line growth across all divisions. Volume ramp up across all divisions provided positive contributions to revenue growth and more than compensated for the weaker dollar.

Furthermore, the shift to early stage accounting for the A400M program increased revenues by €1.1 billion. We will expand on the EBIT explanation shortly, and I will emphasize the good underlying performance.
Order intake over the full year remained strong, containing considerable order inflow from Airbus, Defence, Eurocopter and MTA for the tankers.

Backlog remains at record levels, increasing 18% compared to 2007 figures. The backlog is now benefiting from a strengthening dollar rate due to the revaluation impact at the closing spot rate of 139 dollar versus euro at the end of December versus 147 at the end of December 2007 worth around €10 billion.

If we turn the page and come to page nine, this slide demonstrates the underlying EBIT trend in stripping out non-operational and non-recurring items. Firstly, we have explained to you the impact on the accounts of the shift to early stage accounting, and the resulting charge on the A400M. The business update of loss making contracts amounts to approximately €1 billion for 2008, mainly relating to A380.

The increase incorporates the latest change to the A380 production plan in 2009 and some higher recurring costs reflecting the ramp-up challenges we are facing. You are aware that as the dollar fluctuates so do our loss making contract provisions that are revalued at the closing spot. This now includes two components: the effect from the dollar and the declining British pound.

And a significant portion of our costs are denominated in pounds. The recent weakening of the pound against the euro has triggered another positive currency component. The combination of the dollar rebound and the pound decline has led to a positive revaluation of all loss making contracts amounting to around €900 million.
The benefit from the temporary excess volume of matured hedges, representing the hedges put in place before the A380 delivery shift in 2006 has now fully reversed as expected.

During the year, other one-offs include the dollar mismatch impact coming from the reversal of pre-delivery payments, the revaluation of trade liabilities, the sell-down and provision release of customer financing at Airbus and a provision revaluation of, for Power8.
Up to page 10, EBIT margin has reached 6.5% for the year 2008. R&D increased to almost €2.7 billion. The increase is a result of higher innovation led R&D at Eurocopter and Airbus.

The interest result mainly reflects a strong net cash balance throughout 2008. Meanwhile the other financial result is roughly stable. It includes the unwinding of the discounts on provisions whose present value grows as we move towards their consumption. The positive valuation of the premium paid for options and the revaluation of cash balances due to foreign exchange effects. It also includes some embedded derivatives and treasury swap operations.

The strong earnings improvement led to a tax expense of €703 million, compared to a tax benefit of €333 million last year. Our tax rate for the year is 31%. On the bottom-line it leads to a net income of €1.57 billion for 2008 compared to a net loss of €446 million for 2007.

Up to slide 11, you are aware that our portfolio of hedges now contains forward, structured forward and plain-vanilla euro call option. Options added during the summer period amounted to $9 billion, improving our level of protection and flexibility especially. Due to the strengthening value of the U.S. dollar, the mark-to-market value of our hedge book has decreased by around €5 billion, compared to December 2007 and now amounts to €200 million.

The volatility of the dollar, the change in mark-to-market and the risk pricing of financial institutions make hedging implementation more difficult or impossible with a number of banks. Despite that and due to the rebound in the dollar, we increased the pace of our hedging activity.

Our hedge book further increased from 51 billion last year to $68 billion. While $16.4 billion of hedges matured, $34.6 billion of new hedges were added in 2008 at an average rate of 142 if we exclude the option. Regardless of the pace at which we hedge our activities, we always ensure net exposure for the next two years to be nearly hedged.
Turning to slide 12, cash flow generations for 2008 is better than expected. We finished the year with a net cash position of €9.2 billion, which provides a solid liquidity base for the future.

Gross cash flow from operations was €4.6 billion, thanks to a solid operational performance translated through the net income. It was weighed down by cash consumption of provisions including A400M effects.

Overall, PDPs were still growing across all divisions including Airbus. The deterioration in working capital is attributable to a lower level of advance payments received compared to 2007 level when Astrium benefited from a significant slowdown for Paradigm. You can see it on the slide, it was 1.2, 1.1 to 1.2 billion. Around half of the customer advances are generated by non-Airbus activities.

Lower customer advances were partially offset by a lower ramp-up in inventory versus one year ago in particular at Airbus and MTA. The change in working capital now contains the net effect of customer financing, following a change in presentation under IFRS. 2007 figures have been restated to incorporate this change.

The payments for option premiums are reported in the working capital. They are around 300 million. As expected, we began to support some customers during the fourth quarter. Sales financing represented a cash outflow of approximately €300 million in the year.

Investing activities consumed €1.8 billion of cash in 2008. CapEx at Astrium was lower than last year due to a lower level of investments in Paradigm. The cash contribution to pension plan assets increased versus 2007, and free cash flow was €2.6 billion for the year.
We will now dig into each division's performance, and Louis's going to start on the Airbus slide, which is on page 14.

Thank you Hans Peter. Airbus delivered a solid set of results in 2008 with record deliveries and a growing backlog. With the record order backlog, Airbus has some flexibility to adapt each customer's wish to reschedule some deliveries. With significant progress on Power8, Airbus is preparing to face economic challenges.

Revenues increased by 9% due to stronger volume and a favorable mix. Revenues also include an effect from the shift to early stage accounting for the A400M program, reflecting Airbus work share €765 million.

Overall revenue growth was weighted down by dollar headwind and price deterioration on deliveries. The business delivered a strong EBIT recovery versus last year due to a good underlying business performance and seamless ramp-up on the A320 and A330, less exceptional program and restructuring charges and significant gains from foreign currency from both the U.S. dollar and the British pound.

The A380 costs represent a run-up of changes we are facing. Back ended facing of R&D, non-series cost, sales financing and the reversal of excess temporary volume from hedging weighed on the fourth quarter as anticipated.

Airbus continues to expand its industrial footprints, the new A320 final assembly line in Tianjin will secure access to the Chinese market as well as taping into the country's brightest engineering talents.

The A350 XWB passed its detailed definition freeze review called M5 at, as across the level in December. For the first time, Airbus has a single Digital-Mock-Up and the single tool-set uniting the whole A350 team both within Airbus and its supply chain.
Hans Peter now is going to walk you through the other divisions.
Which starts on page 15. As we have already mentioned as of 2009 our Military Transport Aircraft division will be integrated within Airbus and called Airbus Military.

Now let us walk through the 2008 financial advances in the old perimeter. In 2008 revenues increased to €2.8 billion. This figure includes the A400M Power on milestone. The growth is driven by the shift to early stage accounting for the A400M program, resulting in an uplift of €1.1 billion and an increase in invoicing for both the tanker and medium and light activity.

Despite the new charge taken on the A400M program of €41 million, EBIT has improved due to ramp up in tanker activity and less exceptional charges taken then in 2007. Higher end demand for tankers has resulted in the MTA order book expanding to €22.2 billion. We booked 20 tankers in the year with orders from the U.K., Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.

The A400M passed two key events in 2008, the Power-on milestone was reached in March and the flight-tested flew for the first time in December. The second flight test was completed at the end of the January as planned and tests are making progress.
Development of tankers is also progressing. The air-to-air refueling boom system is finalized following several airborne contacts and the fight test campaign for the tanker to Australia is ongoing.

Let's now move to Eurocopter on the next slide. Eurocopter has achieved its second highest level of orders and delivered more helicopters than ever before. The order book is at €13.8 billion, cancellations were limited and concentrated in the civil and corporate segments.

Revenues rose by 7.5% to €4.5 billion due to a 20% ramp up in serial activities. Customer services and development activities also brought strong contributions. EBIT increased by 39% versus 2007. EBIT margin expanded to 6.5%.
Strong volume growth and a better mix more than compensated negative currency effects and higher innovation led R&D mainly related to the EC175 joint development with China.

Industrial partnership has been reinforced with Brazil for the manufacture, assembly and maintenance support of the EC725 as part of a joint declaration on defense cooperation. Eurocopter has achieved major advances in globalization. In the U.S. the armed forces placed an additional order for 44 LUH.

The 50th helicopter was delivered during the year, including the first from the new Mississippi final assembly line. Final qualification for HAP and UHT versions of Tiger occurred in December. This qualification ends the development phase and paves the way for the Tiger's operational entry into service and its use in external operations.

Eurocopter reinforced its European footprint with the first EC135 manufactured in Albacete, delivered to the Spanish Army response unit. More than 30% of Eurocopter's revenues are derived from services in line with its goal of increasing this share to 50% by 2020. Investment in services increased, particularly in the flight simulator sector. The number of power by the hour service contracts increased by 20% and Eurocopter acquired Motorflug, a German maintenance repair and overhaul specialist.

Let's speak about Astrium on the next slide, number 17. Operational execution and efficiency have driven strong, top and bottom line growth in Astrium. The order book is robust at more than €11 billion. Astrium reinforced its competitive positioning in 2008, generating revenues of €4.3 billion, a 21% increased compared to 2007. The main drivers were telecommunication satellites, a ramp up in Ariane 5 production and the completion of Skynet 5 which enables Paradigm to service the U.K. MOD secure communication system. External growth in services came from the acquisition of the majority share in Spot Image.

Astrium grew profitability for the fifth consecutive year and delivered on its margin outlook. EBIT expansion of 34% was driven by a strong focus on productivity for both Ariane and M51 Ballistic Missile Program and growth in services. The solid performance in Paradigm services more than compensated the unfavorable translation effect from the declining British pound to euro foreign exchange rate.

Astrium's contributions to the internal, international, sorry, space station achieved technical success as the Columbus Laboratory and Automated Transfer Vehicle connected with the ISS in space early in 2008. ESA has since commissioned Astrium with the European share of the ISS operation service contract to 2010.

France's new generation M51 ballistic missile completed its third qualification flight and proved its underwater launch capability. Bolt on investments in services enable Astrium to deliver a full range of integrated earth observation services. Furthermore, the acquisition of SSTL is finalized, which increases capabilities for the design and manufacture of small and micro satellites.

Let's move onto defence on page or slide 18. The order book of €17 billion continues to shift towards high growth products and services. Revenues grew 5% lifted by new growth areas and the consolidation of plant CML from May onwards.

The early stage accounting adjustment made for the A400M generated a revenue increase of €171 million. The division delivered a year of record profitability with EBIT margin increasing to 7.2% due to operating improvement across all businesses driven by maturing programs and cost reduction initiatives.

Eurofighter Tranche 1 is fully delivered. For Tranche 2 partner nations and export deliveries are underway. Discussions are ongoing on Eurofighter Tranche 3. In line with group strategy, security capabilities continue to expand significantly. The acquisition of Plant CML has brought access to the U.S market.

The effectiveness of the Tetra Network was demonstrated by the vital role played in the safety of the Beijing Olympics. Delivery milestones were achieved for the two French programs PARC and SIDM. SIDM is now in service in Afghanistan supporting the French troops. Furthermore, aerial target drones were delivered to the U.S army.

Defence electronics has made inroads in naval radar with customers such as the U.S. Coast Guard and German Armed Forces. This market should bring further export opportunities. All military air systems in Germany have been consolidated in Manching now enabling EADS to strengthen its customer offering and industrial process.

Now on to other businesses on slide 19, EADS North America is consolidated within these other businesses. 2007 figures have been adjusted accordingly. The different divisions, i.e. for example Eurocopter and defence will continue to report their relevant work share in their results.

The order book has grown to almost €3.4 billion. Growth comes from strong LUH order intake in EADS North America, the high level of cabin interior activity at the Sogerma and 25 new freighter conversions at EFW.

Revenues in other businesses have increase 9% driven by a higher ATR deliverers, the LUH program ramp up at EADS North America and higher passenger seats activity at Sogerma. EBIT is roughly stable due to some negative effect from foreign exchange.

Sogerma finalized the sale of Revima in the October. Operationally Sogerma confirms its recovery. ATR ramped up deliveries in 2008 with 55 aircraft delivered, 42 orders in ATR but 22 cancellations clearly show the weakening regional aircraft market. The ramp up has been stopped.

ATR backlog stands at 160 units. EFW aerostructures will benefit from the cooperation with Lufthansa Technik for the conversion and modification of Airbus aircraft in partnerships with Russian Irkut and UAC on the A320/21 freighter conversion. From January 2009 EFW will be part of the Airbus division.

EADS Socata is classified as held for sale in the 2008 accounts due to the final agreement announced between EADS and the Daher Group for Daher to acquire a 70% majority interest. The sale has since been finalized in January.
Louis will now comment on our guidance on page 21.

Thank you very much, Hans Peter. Now I will share our view of the 2009 outlook. We have begun 2009 with a mixed level of visibility, which at Airbus is satisfactory for the first half of the year. However, the level of uncertainty increases as we look beyond.

Our bottom-up analysis is supported by our backlog and by our recent decision to adjust production rates. On the single aisle family, rates are reduced to 34 aircrafts per month from October 2009, and ramp-up of the long-range family is frozen at 8.5 per month to reflect the weakening outlook.

This analysis shows overbooking for the next years. Nevertheless, this backlog is challenged by the present deterioration of the macroeconomic and traffic indicators. Therefore, we are continuously monitoring the market, our customers and suppliers, ready to adapt our production rates to development of delivery perspectives.

As a result, the management is applying a rolling plan concept besides our commercial backlog, our solid backlog in defence and institutional activities provides a certain level of protection and stability.

EADS expect Airbus to capture between 300 and 400 new gross orders in 2009, which is changing taking into account the current market conditions. Based on the stable delivery assumption of U.S. dollar rates at €1 for US$1.39, EADS revenues should be roughly in line with 2008 level.

Under these assumptions, EBIT before one-off should be down in 2009 but significantly positive supported by robust underlying performance in divisions. Revised industrial plans to complete the A400M program could lead to a significant charge, weighing on EBIT depending on the outcome of negotiations with customers and suppliers.

EBIT will also be negatively impacted by increased research and development expenses, by significant hedging deterioration, price deterioration, increasing customer financing and in-service support costs compared to 2008. This elements will be partly offset by further Power8 cost savings.

Free cash flow for 2009 will reflect some negative impacts from lower customer advances at Airbus and some inventory build-up in the last quarter reflecting the reduction in single aisle production rates. We expect to support our customers in financing their deliveries on a discretionary basis in 2009.

The cash consumption of provisions taken over recent years will also wait on the cash flow. At this stage with the current level of visibility, EADS is not expecting to consume more than €1.5 billion of free cash flow over, after customer financing in 2009.
As soon as the group has better visibility of the outcome of the A400M discussion, the development of its commercial markets EADS will update its guidance more precisely.

Finally, page 22 in view of the cash performance of the group, the Board of Directors will propose a dividend of $0.20 per share to the Annual General Meeting of shareholders, $0.08 higher than last year. The dividend will be paid out of the distributable reserves. The low payout ratio of the dividend acknowledges the turbulent macroeconomic and capital market environment. But the Board of Directors wishes to recognize the importance of shareholder loyalty to EADS, and management wishes to express confidence in the company's medium-term prospects.
Now Hans Peter and myself will now take your questions.

Do not stop our Q&A session will last about 30 minutes. Please introduce yourselves and your company when asking a question. Please limit yourself to two questions at a time. Also as usual please remember to speak clearly and slowly to help all participants, particularly ourselves understand what you're asking. So Hika please go ahead and explain the procedures for the participants.
The first question comes from Celine Fornaro, Merrill Lynch UK.

Yes. Good morning. I just have a one question on your guidance and when you actually saying EBIT for 2009 to be excluding the one-offs below 2008. Are you taking the 2008 EBIT, excluding the one-off as well or your reference is the 2.8 billion?
The reference is the 2.8 billion.
Okay. Thank you very much.
The next question comes from Ben Fidler, Deutsche Bank, UK.

Yes. Good morning. Couple of questions if I could? First one, could you share with us the net level of Power8 savings? Thank you for giving us the gross number, the 1.3 billion, but the net level that was achieved in 2008. The second question is whether you could also just help us understand a little bit some of the moving pieces around the 2009 profit outlook, particularly some of the effects that you talked about. So what sort of scale you would see R&D change, the pricing pressure, incremental Power8 and customer financing provisions? Just some help to understand those movements, thank you.
Hans Peter I think it's for you.
I'm not sure, but I will try Louis thank you. Good morning, Ben first of all.
Thank you.

On net level of Power8, I guess you mean net Power8 net of investments we need to make to in order to get the savings. It is a little bit in excess of a billion if we take it on a netted basis. Secondly, I think you wanted to understand a little bit the movers of the outlook for 2009, correct?
Yes. Please, yes.

So I mean it's clear first of all one big level of uncertainty is A400M and I will not talk about A400M but rather on some of the other elements. I mean there is, as we say, higher R&D. R&D level is in 2008 between 2.6 and 2.7 billion and might reach up to three billion for the full year. But obviously depends, this depends upon also the further development during the year because clearly if markets further would deteriorate we would react. Then another element, where we see some increase, not dramatic but still increase is in support costs in service support costs mainly for our A380 fleet, which is growing and with the number of aircraft and the number of destinations. There will be some more to come in 2009.

And then we have a number of other issues, which are related to currency and to market obviously which are in a way difficult to predict. One is the commercial market. We say we deliver up to the same level we have seen in 2008, which means it could be a bit below. We are closely following that, and in case necessary we obviously would further adapt. We will have to look into the development of customer financing with the expected increase and the assessment of the credit standing of the customers behind those increases. Obviously, there might be some provision to be taken, i.e. some negative EBIT impact. Then we will see most probably the same as we have seen last year a huge volatility in the currencies. Not only the dollar, now we have additionally the pound. And in so far this will fluctuate from closing to closing and makes it challenging obviously to predict.

And finally, we will potentially see a phenomenon which is that in case we would lose loss making provisions simply due to the fact that the dollar strengthens as an example. We would have to account for the aircraft delivered, and this is A380, not at the average cost but at the cost along the learning curve, which obviously would weigh also a little bit on EBIT. So there are a number of issues in 2008. We have to keep in mind, when we, I would say, talk about our outlook.
Thank you.
Next question, please.
The next question comes from Sandy Morris from The Royal Bank of Scotland, UK.

Good morning, everyone. Hope everybody is well. Slightly broad question, which I'm, I suppose is irritating. Given that cash protection is key and given what you've just said about aircraft customer financing, what is your view upon delivering an aircraft or not delivering it in order to avoid financing? In other words, would you take aircraft deliveries down in order to guard your cash?

It's very difficult to answer this question. Because we, we feel that there is a reasonable volume of customer financing we could deliver, linked to our, the level of our net cash for the time being. It means that we have room, but we know that we can't go beyond a certain limit. And it will depend on our capacity to sell down the, our customer financing to other operators and if the market is allowing such as a loan it could increase our capacity. Hans Peter you want to be more complete.

I probably want to add a few things. First of all, Sandy it's clear our customer financing support which we envisage for 2009 cannot obviously solve everything if the financial markets are not working and if ECA agencies would not come up with a significantly increased frame of export guarantees. Which by the way is very, on a very good track and looked at very constructively by our nations. So, yes, we might refrain from delivering aircraft. In case we come to the conclusion that the credit standing is not good enough. The pre-condition for that is obviously that this is not happening last minute. In other words in a situation where the aircraft is already built and more or less on the tarmac, then the, this decision is much more difficult. But in any case, we might refrain not to give the support and as a consequence not deliver. And by the way, we are currently already envisaging that in not taking into account overbooking which still exists. So there is still a very small level of overbooking on 2009 and more significant in 2010 and more, even more significant in 2011.

So already now we envisage not to satisfy all the customers which are in the order backlog of today. I mean the process is one, which is followed online, I would say, every two weeks we are meeting in a risk management committee to look at that and to take decisions proactively. And proactively means four to six months before a delivery on single aisle and probably eight to ten months on a long range, where you already have to decide whether you customize the aircraft or not.
Okay. Thank you very much for that. And good luck to us all, I think.
Next question?
The next question comes from Antoine Boivin from Cheuvreux, France. Please go ahead with your question.

Hi, Antoine Boivin-Champeaux from Cheuvreux. Good morning, Louis, Hans Peter, Nathalie. I have two questions. First of all, could you tell us what percentage of the aircraft value the export credit agencies are currently ready to guarantee, that's my first question. Is there a change as compared to last year, thanks to government support so I would be interested in the level. Secondly, could you tell us regarding Power8 what is the net contribution within the P&L and not as a net of cost issue that you mentioned before? Thank you.

On ECA, Louie if allow, roughly 50% of the deliveries are expected to be supported by the ECAs. That is the current level of discussion we have in the, in our European capital. And obviously the ECAs are doing their due diligence in each and every case. But this is I think where we can count on for the time being. On net contribution in the P&L, it's, I mean, we are deliberately or intentionally not giving a figure here because we are following those projects on a project-by-project basis and as the savings have materialized they are reported in a reporting tool. To flow it down into the EBIT line is rather complicated not the least because it, a lot of it is or some of it is flowing through inventories. So to give you a precise number on EBIT is difficult and so it's more of a guess and.
What's your guess?
Yeah, so in so far we don't give you the precise number for it, sorry.
Okay. Thank you.
On to the next question please.
The next question comes from William Mackie from Main First UK. Please go ahead with your question.

Yes, good morning. It's Will Mackie from Main First. One real question to focus on cash flow in a number of parts, could you just step us through some of your assumptions behind the 1.5 billion cash outflow? Particularly, how you see provision utilization developing in terms of cash burn for '09? And on the customer financing side what are your assumptions about the level of capital you may allocate to customer financing in this year? And lastly, you've mentioned the potential build-up for inventories towards the end of the year. What sort of assumptions are you making about working capital development as we go through '09?

Some of the elements were to start with provision utilization. Yes, there are significant provisions in our balance sheet, which flow through the cash flows over the next years to come. The level now excluding the A400M is about 2.6, 2.7 billion in total. 1.5 billion out of this will be turned within the years 2009, '10, '11, and the remaining ones in the years after so there are some cash outs we have envisaged within the number you have. The customer financing, we have given you some I would say flavor on what we expect on the customer financing. Already it is between, let me look, it's, I mean we didn't put a figure on the slide, but what we said is already that it is roughly the level we had during the last cycle which is on a yearly basis probably around or close to €1 billion. On.
A bit less on a net basis because some of them are.

We were obviously structured as we did in the past to be able to sell it down at anytime so we are not there to keep this exposure, and you've seen that we successful sold down a lot of this exposure. We have obviously, we envisaged to have some decrease in pre-delivery payments compared to 2008. So the inflow is probably not at the same level.
